The Regina campus building was designed by architect [[Douglas Cardinal]]. ==Basic information== {{Weasel|date=April 2010}}{{Unreferenced section|date=December 2009}} Although it is called the First Nations University of Canada (FNUniv) and is recognized as a university by the Saskatchewan Government, the institution is actually a federated college of the University of Regina (U of R), and its degrees are recognized as U of R degrees. The enabling legislation is ''An Act Respecting the University of Regina, Chapter U-5.'' http://www.qp.gov.sk.ca/publications/index.cfm?fuseaction=details&c=2036&id=2 ''The University of Regina Act.'' The top two and a half floors of its Regina campus building are leased as office space to Indian and Northern Affairs Canada (INAC) who assist and oversee daily operations of the university. FNUniv students at the Regina campus pay regular U of R related and University of Regina Student Union fees. Like the other federated colleges of Luther and Campion, FNUniv students may utilize all of the U of R facilities (libraries, book stores, clubs, parking, labs, etc.) and services (meal plans, residences, web/on-line services, career counselling, etc.). The FNUniv degree programs are correlated with the rest of the U of R curriculum. FNUniv is open to students of all cultures and nationalities and not restricted only to those of First Nations descent. ==History== [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex]] opened the university in 2003.{{cite news |url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2003/06/21/fnuniv_030621.html |title = Canada's first aboriginal-run university opens |publisher = CBC News |date = June 21, 2003 |accessdate = 2010-02-01}} [[Queen Elizabeth II]], [[Monarchy in Canada|Queen of Canada]], made it her first engagement during the centennial celebrations of Saskatchewan and Alberta in 2005. {{Cquote2|This stone was taken from the grounds of Balmoral Castle in the Highlands of Scotland â a place dear to my great great grandmother, Queen Victoria. It symbolises the foundation of the rights of First Nations peoples reflected in treaties signed with the Crown during her reign. Bearing the cipher of Queen Victoria as well as my own, this stone is presented to the First Nations University of Canada in the hope that it will serve as a reminder of the special relationship between the Sovereign and all First Nations peoples.[http://www.monarchist.ca/new/quotes.html Elizabeth II, Queen of Canada, at the First Nations University of Canada, 2005]| Elizabeth II at the First Nations University of Canada, 2005}} [[Star Blanket Cree Nation]] has proposed a plan to declare the institution's property an [[Urban Indian reserve]] under a Saskatchewan Treaty Land Entitlement Agreement involving Star Blanket, the provincial and federal governments. Band members of the Star Blanket Nation unanimously voted in favour of this plan during a 2008 referendum.{{cite news | url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/releases/archive/May2008/17/c9836.html | accessdate=2008-05-17 | title=100 per cent Vote in Favour of Urban Reserve Proposal | date=17 May 2008 | publisher=[[CNW Group]] | author=First Nations University of Canada}} ==Partnerships== [[Image:First Nations University, University of Regina.jpg|right|thumb|275px|First Nations University of Canada]] [[Image:WilsonSchool.jpg|thumb|right|First Nations University Campus in Saskatoon]] [[Image:FirstNations University of Canada.jpg|thumb|right|First Nations University Campus in Saskatoon]] [[Image:Wilson Public School-FirstNationsUniversity.jpg|thumb|right|First Nations University Campus in Saskatoon]] [[Image:FirstNationsUniversity.jpg|thumb|right|First Nations University Campus in Saskatoon]] The Saskatchewan Indian Federated College was affiliated from the first with the [[University of Regina]]. It was founded in 1976 by an agreement between the Federation of Saskatchewan Indian Nations and the University of Regina, with the stated intent of serving "the academic, cultural and spiritual needs of First Nations' students".[http://www.sasknetwork.gov.sk.ca/html/Learners/educationtraining/federatedcolleges.htm SaskNetWork - Federated Colleges] ==Aboriginal programs== The university designed special programs in partnership with Aboriginal communities to meet the human resource needs of Aboriginal communities in areas such as health, education and the environment - examples include its National School of Dental Therapy, Nursing and Health Studies programs. A special first-year bridging programs for Aboriginal students is provided, with Aboriginal Elders present on campus to provide social supports. FNUniv offers a comprehensive career services program to meet the vocational problems of Aboriginal students. .{{cite web | last = Mendelson | first = Michael | authorlink = | coauthors = Alex Usher | title = The Aboriginal University Education Roundtable | work = | publisher = University of Winnipeg | date = 2007-05-24 | url = http://www.uwinnipeg.ca/index/cms-filesystem-action?file=pdfs/conferences/2007/aboriginal-rt-spring-report.pdf | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-01-28}} ==Controversies== ===Professional standing=== In May 2007, the university was put on probation by the [[Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada|AUCC]], following a controversy in February 2005, in which the university fired a number of staff members. The association demanded the university establish full independence from the [[Federation of Saskatchewan Indian Nations]] within a year.{{cite web |url = http://chronicle.com/weekly/v53/i35/35a04703.htm |title = Canada's Only Aboriginal-Controlled University is Placed on Probation |last = Birchard |first = Karen |date = May 4th, 2007 |publisher = The Chronicle of Higher Education |accessdate = 2009-12-06}} The university complied with the AUCC directives, and was reinstated in April 2008.{{cite news | title = First Nations University back in AUCC's good books | work = | publisher = CBC News | date = 2008-04-02 | url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/saskatchewan/story/2008/04/02/fnuc-aucc.html | doi = | accessdate = 2008-04-03}} In November 2008, the [[Canadian Association of University Teachers]] voted unanimously to censure FNUniv and asked its members not accept jobs, honours or awards at the university. Changes made relating to academic freedom, governance and political autonomy were reported to be reason for the censure vote.{{cite news | title = University teachers group censures First Nations University of Canada | work = | publisher = CBC News | date = 2008-12-01 | url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/saskatchewan/story/2008/12/01/fnuc-caut.html | doi = | accessdate = 2008-12-01}} The censure was lifted in April 2010 after the university made very significant governance changes. {{cite web|url=http://www.caut.ca/news_details.asp?nid=1481&page=490 |title=Delegates to CAUTâs national Council vote unanimously to lift censure of First Nations University of Canada |accessdate=2010-09-11}} ===Financial support=== In October 2008, the government of Saskatchewan gave the university [[Canadian dollar|$]]1.6 million to relieve a chronic budget deficit. The money was given to cover salaries of faculty and operating expenses. Another $400,000 was to be spent on a review of the university's long-term operations.{{cite news | title = Bailout helps First Nations University with 'acute financial situation' | work = | publisher = CBC News | date = 2008-10-07 | url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/saskatchewan/story/2008/10/07/fnuc-money.html | doi = | accessdate = 2008-10-08}}{{cite web | last = Graham | first = Jennifer | title = Struggling First Nations University gets $1.6M from Saskatchewan government | publisher = Canadian Press | date = 2008-10-07 | url = http://news.therecord.com/Wire/News_Wire/National/article/425871 | accessdate = 2010-02-04}} In February 2009, the provincial government withheld $200,000 of funding. Lack of progress in solving the institution's problems was cited as the reason.{{cite web | last = Warick | first = Jason | title = Gov't freezes FNUC funding | work = [[The StarPhoenix]] | publisher accessdate = 2009-01-14}} In December 2009 the university's chief financial officer, Murray Westerlund, left his position. Westerlund said he was fired, but FUNiv's then-President Charles Pratt said the departure was mutually agreed upon.{{cite news |url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/saskatchewan/story/2009/12/04/sk-fnuc-cfo-departure-91204.html |title = First Nations University loses chief financial officer |publisher = CBC News |date = December 4, 2009 |accessdate = 2009-12-04}} FNUniv officials also missed another series of deadlines to file various reports, which led the federal government to withhold $1.8 million in funding.{{cite web |url = http://www.thestarphoenix.com/news/FNUC+misses+reporting+deadlines/2306777/story.html |title = FNUC misses reporting deadlines |last = Warick |first = Jason |date = December 6, 2009 |work = [[The StarPhoenix]] |publisher = [[CanWest]] |accessdate = 2009-12-06}} In January 2010, documents from November 2009 surfaced which showed that Westerlund had raised concerns about inappropriate spending.{{cite news |url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/saskatchewan/story/2010/01/22/sk-fnuc-finances-100122.html |title = Minister calls for emergency meeting on First Nations University |publisher = CBC News |date = January 22, 2010 |accessdate = 2010-01-22}} Westerlund filed a wrongful dismissal lawsuit against the university on December 17, 2009. The suit claims he was marginalized and then fired for writing the documents which criticized the spending practices of university officials.{{cite web |url = http://www.thestarphoenix.com/news/sues+FNUC/2475557/story.html |title = Ex-CFO sues FNUC |last = Warick |first = Jason |work = [[The StarPhoenix]] |publisher = [[CanWest]] |date = January 22, 2010 |accessdate = 2010-01-25}} The provincial Minister of Advanced Education, [[Rob Norris]], called for an emergency meeting with the [[University of Regina]]'s board of governors to discuss the financial situation at the FNUniv.{{cite web |url = http://www.thestarphoenix.com/FNUC+allegations+disturb+Norris/2480639/story.html |title = FNUC allegations 'disturb' Norris |last = Maclean |first = Rory |work = [[The StarPhoenix]] |publisher = [[CanWest]] |date = January 25, 2010 |accessdate = 2010-01-25}} After the meeting on January 27, Norris hinted that the provincial government may cut off funding to the institution.{{cite news |url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/saskatchewan/story/2010/01/28/sk-minister-fnuc-1001.html |title = Sask. may cut funding to First Nations University |publisher = CBC News |date = January 28, 2010 |accessdate = 2010-01-2008}} In March 2010, it was discovered that nearly $400,000 of the FNUniv's scholarship fund had been spent on general operations. The fund had dwindled from $390,000 in spring 2009 to just $15,000 in February 2010.{{cite web |url = http://www.thestarphoenix.com/Nearly+400K+from+FNUC+scholarship+fund+used+former+administration/2658657/story.html |title = Nearly $400,000 from FNUC scholarship fund used by former administration |last = Wood |first = James |coauthors = Jason Warick |work = [[The StarPhoenix]] |publisher = [[CanWest]] |date = March 8, 2010 |accessdate = 2010-03-09}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On March 19, 2010, Charles Pratt was terminated by the Interim Board of Governors, with cause, as President of FNUniv; he had previously been suspended with pay.http://www.newstalk650.com/story/20100319/30968 Dr. Shauneen Pete, who had formerly been dismissed from a leadership post at FNUNiv, was appointed as President in April 2010{{cite web |url = http://www.leaderpost.com/Shauneen+Pete+begins+month+term+FNUniv+president/2754868/story.html |title = Shauneen Pete begins six-month term as FNUniv president |last = Benjoe |first = K |work = Leader-Post |date = April 5, 2010}} On June 9th 2011, Wesley Robert Stevenson, a former top official with FNUC, plead guilty to charges of fraud. Between January and March of 2005 Stevenson spent $15000 from the Canadian Federal government (originally intended for a FNUC trip to Scotland) on a 'working holiday' for himself as well as other FNUC expenses. The CBC reported that Stevenson had already made full restitution before pleading guilty. {{cite news |url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/story/2011/06/09/sk-stevenson-fraud.html |title = Former FNUC official pleads guilty to fraud |date = June 9, 2011 | work=CBC News}} ==See also== {{portal|University of the Arctic}} *[[First Nations University Students' Association]] *[[Higher education in Saskatchewan]] *[[Alfred Young Man]], professor, curator, and department head of Indian Fine Arts[http://people.uleth.ca/~youngman/ "Alfred Young Man, PhD."] ''University of Lethbridge: People.''
